The catalytic oxidation of CO by single-atom transition metal catalysts has always been the focus of researchers. Herein, we report a strategy for the preparation of Cu single-atom anchored on MnO2 by oxalate chelation-assisted hydrothermal method, and the obtained Cu/MnO2–0.25 catalyst with the optimal molar ratio achieved about 90% CO conversion at 80 °C. The strong electronic interaction between Cu and MnO2 not only effectively inhibits the aggregation of Cu single atoms, but also the formed Cu-O-Mn hybrid structure activates the adjacent surface lattice oxygen, further improving the catalytic oxidation performance of CO at low and medium temperatures. The elevated activity is achieved at the single-atom active site by the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. This work provides a simple and reliable method for the rational design of stable transition metal single-atom catalysts and deepens the understanding of metal-support strong interactions (SMSI). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu single-atom catalyst CO oxidation Surface lattice oxygen MvK mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The iron and steel industry is one of the main sources of air pollution [1], in which a large amount of CO gas can be generated in the sintering process and discharged into the atmosphere to pollute the environment [2]. As an energy-saving and efficient method for CO removal, catalytic oxidation has become a common choice for practical applications and theoretical research [3,4]. If the heating device in the denitration device can be replaced with a device for catalytic oxidation of CO, it can not only remove the CO in the flue gas, but also raise the temperature of the flue gas to provide heat for the subsequent selective catalytic reduction (SCR) reaction. This efficient method not only eliminates pollution, but also saves a significant portion of heating costs. The key to the catalytic oxidation of CO lies in the design of catalysts. In recent years, various types of single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been developed and used to catalyze the oxidation of CO [5,6]. The first defined SAC is Pt1/FeOx with a loading of 0.17 wt% exhibiting high CO catalytic performance, providing clear evidence of the role and mechanism of single atoms in the CO oxidation process [7]. Subsequently, researchers turned their attention to noble metals (Au, Pd, Ir, Rh…) and maximized the use of noble metals as single-atom active sites to improve catalytic activity [8,9], which has been extensively studied in the fields of electrochemistry and environmental catalysis. However, the natural scarcity, high price, agglomeration, and poisoning of noble metals have hindered their practical application. In the long run, low-cost, structurally tunable, and relatively stable alternatives are worthy of long-term exploration such as transition metals [10]. It is still a challenge to precisely control the stable exposure of Cu single atoms or clusters on the catalyst surface. Therefore, it is crucial to choose a support that can form specific metal sites on the surface and inhibit the aggregation of metal atoms to nanoparticles. In recent years, strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) as an interfacial electronic effect has attracted increasing attention and study by researchers because it is closely related to the charge transfer between metal and supports, which in turn affects the catalytic performance [11]. Numerous studies have verified that the surface oxygen vacancies of metal oxides can provide anchoring sites for single atoms. Single metal atoms interact with neighboring oxygen anions in the form of metal-O-support bonds (SMSI), which may be strongly anchored to the support, leading to the realization of isolated single atoms [12]. Therefore, supports with oxygen defects, such as ZnO, [13,14], MgO, [15], Fe2O3, [16–18], Al2O3, [19,20], CeO2 [21] and TiO2 [22,23] are preferentially selected to utilize surface oxygen anions as ligands to form lone electron pairs on the oxygen to coordinate with the metal, resulting in a single-atom catalyst. Also the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) is an extremely important process in the multiphase catalytic oxidation process [24]. Active surface lattice oxygen has excellent oxidation potential and is widely involved in the multiphase catalytic oxidation process among the various ROSs [25]. And the modulation of metal oxide supports by SMSI can effectively initiate lattice distortion and promote the activation of surface lattice oxygen, thus promoting oxidation activity at low and medium temperatures, which involves the Marsvan Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. Meanwhile, it has been reported that SMSI between single-atom catalysts can dramatically change the morphology and electronic properties of isolated metal, with sufficient electrons available to serve as sites for lattice oxygen activation, leading to oxidation reactions [26]. Based on the above discussion, Cu with d10S1 electronic group and high d-band center [27] was chosen as the dispersed atom and MnO2 with good oxygen activation ability [28] were selected as the supports to prepare the catalysts. Cu single-atom catalysts anchored on MnO2 were prepared using oxalate-chelate assisted hydrothermal method, which exhibited good activity in medium and low temperature CO oxidation reactions. The strong interaction of atomically dispersed Cu and MnO2 led to the formation of hybridized Cu-O-Mn, which lowered the Fermi energy level of the reactive oxygen and generated the activated surface lattice oxygen, further effectively promoting the catalytic oxidation performance [25]. This work not only demonstrated that the formation of transition metal single-atom catalysts greatly contributed to the catalytic oxidation performance on an economical basis, but also extended the understanding of the activation of lattice oxygen molecules by SMSI for promoting the catalytic oxidation process, which was enlightening for both atomic-level studies and practical applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation During the synthesis process, Cu/MnO2 with different molar ratios of Cu to MnO2 of 0.1%,0.25%,0.5% and 1% were prepared by oxalate-chelate assisted hydrothermal method, which were named Cu/MnO2–0.1, Cu/MnO2–0.25, Cu/MnO2–0.5 and Cu/MnO2–1 respectively. The detailed synthesis steps are as follows: First, 0.1 mol potassium permanganate solid was dissolved in 300 mL of deionized water, then 0.05 mol of ammonium oxalate solid was dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water, poured into the above potassium permanganate solution, and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Then the copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) was added to the above mixed solution. After stirring 1 h, the obtained slurries were transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and then subjected to a hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the samples were washed and filtered repeatedly, dried at 105 °C overnight and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h in air. Different concentrations of Cu/MnO2 were obtained by adding different mass of copper nitrate trihydrate. Pure MnO2 solids were obtained without the addition of copper nitrate trihydrate. 2.2 Catalyst activity evaluation The catalytic oxidation of CO was performed on a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor under atmospheric pressure. 3 ml of fresh catalysts of (40–60 meshes) was loaded into a quartz tube with an internal diameter of 12 mm, the simulated flue gas containing 4000 ppm CO, 16 vol% O2 and balanced by Ar. The total flow rate was 1L‧min−1 and the gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 20,000 h−1. The concentrations of all the components were monitored online by a Portable Infrared Flue Gas Analyzer (DX-4000). The catalytic performance evaluation of CO catalytic oxidation is calculated by the following formula (1): (1) C O c o n v e r s i o n = [ C O ] i n − [ C O ] o u t [ C O ] i n × 100 % The effects of condition changes on the catalytic activity of materials were measured by changing the concentration ratio and adding water vapor. The 10 vol% water vapor conditions are obtained by passing the air stream through a water saturator at a specific temperature. 2.3 Kinetics measurements Kinetics measurements are performed by using the same reactor as the catalytic test. In order to obtain accurate kinetic experimental data, we first need to eliminate the effect of internal and external diffusion on CO oxidation activity according to the method proposed in Ref [29]. Therefore, we used mass space velocity of 1200,000 h−1 (to ensure its activity is below 20%), and a catalyst particle diameter of 60–120 meshes as the experimental conditions for the subsequent activation energy test and reaction order test. In addition, the catalyst was diluted 9 times with white quartz sand according to the mass multiple to reduce the heat transfer resistance. The feed gas was equilibrated with 4000 ppm CO, 16 vol% O2, and Ar balanced under the same conditions for measuring catalyst activity [30]. The activation energy tests were carried out in the temperature range of 60–120 °C with CO conversion below 20%. The apparent activation energy (Ea) is calculated as formula (2)(3): (2) k = − ( v m ) ln ( 1 − X C O ) (3) k = A e − E a / R T in which v is total flow of reactive gas, m is the weight of the catalyst (g) and X C O is CO conversion. k is the rate constant, A is the former factor, and T is the temperature (K). Ea is obtained by fitting the value of ln(r) at different temperatures. The reaction order of CO and O2 was tested by changing the partial pressure to maintain a constant flow rate at 120 °C. Reaction order of CO and O2 obtained by fitting LnP and Lnr. The reaction rate (r) is calculated according to formula (4) ensure more realistic catalyst kinetic parameters. (4) r [ m o l g − 1 s − 1 ] = N C O X C O / m in which N C O is the molar flow of CO in the mixture (mol‧s−1), X C O is CO conversion and m is the weight of the catalyst (g). 2.4 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (K = 0.15418 nm,40 kV and 40 mA), the scanning range is 5–90°(2θ) and the scanning rate is 10°/min. Raman spectra was collected by DXR Raman Microscope (ThermoFisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, MA, USA) under excitation of 455 nm laser at the range from 300 cm−1 to 700 cm−1. The accurate content of metals in the sample was determined by inductively coupled optical plasma emission spectrometer. (ICP-OES:PerkinElmer 8300). The specific surface areas (SBET) and BJH pore-size distribution of the catalyst was measured by the Quantachrome AutoSorb iQ-MP automatic gas adsorption system. The adsorbate was high-purity N2, and the adsorption temperature was 77 k. The samples need to be degassed in vacuum at 300 °C for 6 h before testing. HR-TEM images were obtained on the JEM-2100F equipment and the acceleration voltage was 200 kV. The prepared samples were dispersed in anhydrous ethanol solution and ultrasonicated for 5 min, dropped onto the ultra-thin carbon film, and tested after drying. The EDS determined whether elements are evenly distributed on the carrier. The EDS images can get the chemical composition and whether the elements are evenly distributed. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analyzed the chemical composition and chemical valence state of the catalyst surface. The experiments used an AXIS ULTRA DLD electron spectrometer with Al Kα (1486.8 eV) radiation, and the binding energy of C 1 s 284.8 eV was the calibration of the binding energy (BE) values. Cu K-edge analysis was performed with Si (111) crystal monochromators at the BL14W1 beamlines at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) (Shanghai, China). Before the analysis at the beamline, samples were pressed into thin sheets with 1 cm in diameter and sealed using Kapton tape film. The XAFS spectra were recorded at room temperature using a 4-channel Silicon Drift Detector (SDD) Bruker 5040.Cu K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were recorded in transmission mode. Negligible changes in the line-shape and peak position of Cu K-edge XANES spectra were observed between two scans taken for a specific sample. The XAFS spectra of these standard samples (Cu foil, CuO, and Cu2O) were recorded in fluorescence mode. The spectra were processed and analyzed by the software codes Athena and Artemis [31]. Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD, 3% O2/He) were also performed on an Auto Chem II 2920 automated chemisorption analyzer. A 20 mg sample was weighed into a U-shaped tube, pretreated with 30 mL min−1 He at 300 °C for 40 min to remove oxygen and other impurities adsorbed in the air, and then cooled to 40 °C. Then adsorbed 1 h in 30 mL/min 3% O2/He atmosphere to make the catalyst adsorption saturated and purged with 30 mL/min He to desorb the physically adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst. Heated from 40 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to analyze the effluent gas. Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR, 10% H2/Ar) were performed on an Auto Chem II 2920 automated chemisorption analyzer. A 20 mg sample was weighed into a U-shaped tube, pretreated with 30 mL/min Ar at 300 °C for 40 min to remove oxygen and other impurities adsorbed in the air, and then cooled to 40 °C. It was purged with 10% H2/Ar for 30 min, and then heated from 40 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to analyze the effluent gas. The amount of oxygen involved in the MvK mechanism on the catalyst was determined using a CO pulse injection experiment. The experiments were carried out on an Auto Chem II 2920 automated chemisorption analyzer as follows: 100 mg of catalyst was placed in a U-shaped reaction tube, purged for 1 h at 350 °C under He atmosphere and then cooled down to 120 °C. Ten CO pulses (10% CO/He) were injected into the sample at 120 °C to ensure saturation and five CO pulses were calibrated using a pulsed quantification ring (volume 519 µl) to determine the total CO adsorbed by the catalyst and finally to calculate the oxygen consumption. In situ Diffusion reflectance infrared Fourier transform (In situ-DRIFT) spectra characterization was often used to detect intermediates produced in the reaction, which can be used to determine the mechanism of CO oxidation on catalysts. The experiment was operated on a Bruker Tensor27 with an MCT detector. The spectra were obtained with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and the scanning range is 800–3800 cm−1. Before experiment, the sample was pretreated under N2 at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled the temperature required for the reaction. Next passed the reaction atmosphere into the reaction cell, and continuously collected infrared spectra. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Comparing the catalytic activities of Cu-doped MnO2 catalysts and pure MnO2 supports, the catalytic performances of Cu/MnO2 and pure MnO2 with different Cu contents tested at 60–180 °C were shown in Fig. 1 a [32]. The CO conversion of all catalysts increased with increasing of reaction temperature. The order of T90 for different catalysts was: Cu/MnO2–0.25>Cu/MnO2–0.5>Cu/MnO2–1>Cu/MnO2–0.1>MnO2. With the increase of Cu content, the activity of the Cu/MnO2 catalyst showed a trend of first increase and then decrease, Cu/MnO2 with 0.25% theoretical Cu content achieved the highest catalytic activity. Cu/MnO2–0.25 could realize 100% conversion of CO at 100 °C, much better than MnO2. Then, taking into account the effect of water vapor in the actual sintering flue gas, we added 10 vol% water vapor under the original conditions, and continuously measured the catalytic activity of the catalyst. We found that in the presence of water, all the catalysts exhibited a negative effect on CO conversion, which was mainly attributed to the competitive adsorption of oxygen and water molecules at the active sites, making it difficult for the active sites to oxidize CO, thus reducing the catalytic activity [33,34]. However, Cu/MnO2–0.25 still shows higher activity than the others. The stability test of Cu/MnO2–0.25 was carried out at 120 °C for 60 h (Fig. 1d), and its activity remained above 99%, indicating that it has relatively stable catalytic performance. These results showed that the MnO2 support can significantly improve the catalytic oxidation activity of CO after loading Cu single atoms, indicating that the metal-support interaction between Cu and the MnO2 support can effectively promote the oxidation of CO at medium and low temperatures [35]. To verify the superior CO oxidation performance of Cu single-atom catalyst prepared by oxalate chelation-assisted hydrothermal method, CuO-MnO2–0.25 catalyst with the same content of 0.25% was prepared by the impregnation method, the catalytic performance of CuO-MnO2–0.25 was much lower than that of Cu/MnO2–0.25, and its T90 was increased to 90 °C. In addition, the catalytic performance of CuO-MnO2–0.25 was also lower than that of Cu/MnO2–0.25 under the condition of 10 vol% water vapor. This indicated that the Cu single-atom catalyst prepared by the hydrothermal method has higher catalytic activity than general nanocatalysts due to its strong electronic interaction (SMSI) between Cu and supports and high atom utilization. To further explore the performance of the catalyst, the apparent activation energy (Ea) of the catalyst was calculated using the Arrhenius function (K = A•exp(-Ea/RT)). It was worth noting that to obtain accurate kinetic data, we used a mass space velocity of 1200,000 h−1, (to ensure that the CO conversion rate was below 20%) and 60/120 meshes catalyst particle diameter were used as experimental conditions for kinetic testing, and the reaction was assumed to be pseudo-first-order reaction. As displayed in Fig. 1b, Ea values were varied with the embedding Cu content in the catalyst and the minimum value is obtained to be 38.74 kJ/mol for Cu/MnO2–0.25, which is consistent with catalytic activities of catalysts. Therefore, the doping of Cu lowers the energy barrier during CO oxidation. 3.2 Crystal structure and morphology of catalyst The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of all samples were typical Langmuir IV curves with H1 hysteresis loops (Fig. S1a) [36,37], and the pore size distribution diagrams showed that the sample pore size distributions are concentrated in 3–20 nm (Fig. S2a), indicating that the catalysts were all mesoporous structures [38]. The specific surface area (SBET), pore volume and average pore diameter (DBJH) were calculated from the isotherms, and the results were shown in Table 1 . With the introduction of Cu, the SBET value of the samples basically showed a gradually increasing trend, which indicated that the introduction of Cu atoms would increase the specific surface area of the catalysts, and Cu/MnO2–0.25 had the largest pore volume and average pore size, which was beneficial to the gas diffusion. This all corresponded to its superior oxidation activity compared with MnO2. XRD characterization (Fig. 2 a) showed that MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 displayed similar characteristic peaks, all characteristic X-ray powder diffraction peaks (XRD) matched well with the standard card (JCPDS 72–1982) [39], which indicated that the introduction of Cu species had little effect on the crystal structure of MnO2. No characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to Cu or its oxides were observed, which may be due to the high degree of metal dispersion [10] or the metal loading is below the detection limit of XRD [40]. At the same time. The strongest peaks of MnO2 were located at 28.7° and 37.5°, corresponding to the (310) and (121) planes slightly shifted to smaller 2θ angles after the introduction of Cu species. It was possible that a small number of Cu ions were doped into the MnO2 framework by considering the big radii and the low charge of the Cu ions (the ionic radii of Cu2+ and Cu+ are 0.73 and 0.77 Å, while those of Mn4+ and Mn3+ are 0.53 and 0.65 Å respectively) [41]. This lattice change was further verified by Raman spectroscopic analysis of the samples (Fig. 2b). The Raman spectral peaks in the range of 550–650 cm−1 can correspond to the Mn-O bonds in the MnO6 octahedron [42]. It can be seen that the peak intensity of the Mn-O bond broadened and weakened with the introduction of Cu, and the peak position decreased from MnO2 (636 cm−1) to Cu/MnO2–0.25 (633 cm−1) [43], which indicated that the formation of hybridized Cu-O-Mn through strong metal-support interactions weakened the Mn-O bond and generated more lattice defects, thus increasing the surface lattice oxygen mobility [44]. The HR-TEM characterizations of MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 were shown in the Fig. 3 a-h. Both samples exhibited nanorod morphology. No Cu nanoclusters or nanoparticles were clearly observed on Cu/MnO2–0.25, because when the metal loading was lower than 1%, it was difficult to visually observe the presence of metal on the surface of the sample by HRTEM images. We used EDS images to demonstrate the presence of Cu, as shown in Fig. 3i, Cu, Mn, and O were uniformly dispersed on the surface of MnO2. Observing Fig. 3d and h, it can be found that the introduction of Cu changed the lattice spacing of the catalyst, which was consistent with the results of XRD and Raman spectroscopy, both of which demonstrated that the introduction of Cu changed the lattice structure of the catalysts. 3.3 Coordination and electronic structure of catalyst Fig. 4 a showed the Cu Kedge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Cu foil, CuO, CuO2, and synthetic Cu/MnO2–0.25 catalyst. XANES spectroscopy can be used to analyze the valence of the catalysts. The displacement of the absorption Kedge showed the valence [45]. The higher the valence state, the more the absorption edge shifted to the higher energy direction. As shown in Fig. 4a, the valence of Cu in Cu/MnO2–0.25 was between Cu2O and CuO. The Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis was shown in Fig. 4b. The Cu/MnO2–0.25 spectra were completely different from those of CuO and Cu2O, excluding the presence of catalysts in the form of either. There was a distinct peak only at 1.5 Å in the first shell. It is proved that the catalyst was dominated by Cu-O bond, and there is no Cu-Cu bond, conclusively confirming the single atomic dispersion of the Cu ion in Cu/MnO2–0.25. The oxidative ability of a catalyst is directly related to its redox state. Therefore, the valence state and surface composition of the catalysts were investigated using XPS. The fitting results of XPS spectra of O 1 s, Mn 2p and Mn 3 s of MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 were shown in Fig. 5 . The specific content ratio and oxidation state calculation results were shown in Table 2 . Because the content of Cu on the catalyst surface was below the minimum detection limit of XPS, Cu species were not detected by XPS. Fig. 5a showed the fitted peaks of the Mn 2p3/2 XPS spectrum ascribed to the Mn3+ and Mn4+ species. With the addition of Cu atoms, both the proportion of Mn4+ and AOS value calculated by Mn 3S increased, indicating an enhanced redox capacity due to the formation of single-atom catalysts [46]. To further verify this conclusion, we compared the difference in oxygen content of the two samples (Fig. 5c). The O 1 s spectra of MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 was divided into two distinct peaks, concentrated at 531 eV and 529.7 eV, representing Oα (surface adsorbed oxygen) and Oβ (surface lattice oxygen) [47,48]. It can be observed from Table 2 that the Oβ content was dominant in the catalyst. It can be preliminarily considered that the CO oxidation reaction may follow the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [49]. Also, it was found that the content of lattice oxygen increased after the introduction of Cu, indicating that the formation of single-atom catalysts activated more surface lattice oxygen to participate in the reaction and enhanced the catalytic oxidation performance [50]. 3.4 Redox properties of catalyst O2-TPD is an effective technique to study the dissociation behavior of O2 on catalysts, and it is often used to study the mobility and activation ability of different oxygen species on catalysts (Fig 6 a). In general, the peak position of O2-TPD spectrum could be divided into three regions: low temperature (<300 °C), medium temperature (300–600 °C), and high temperature (>600 °C), corresponding to surface adsorbed oxygen (Oad) and surface lattice oxygen (S-Olatt) and bulk lattice oxygen (B-Olatt) [51]. For pure MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25, the peak of Oad was indistinct, while clear peaks were observed between 300 and 600 °C and in the >600 °C region. Normally, the oxidation reaction generally obeyed MvK mechanism that was closely related to Olatt [49]. MnO2 exhibited an obvious S-Olatt desorption peak at 584 °C and B-Olatt desorption peak at 716 °C, while the Olatt desorption peaks of Cu/MnO2–0.25 shifted to lower temperature region (574 °C and 708 °C). This demonstrated that strong interactions between Cu atoms and MnO2 allowed the migration and activation of more Olatt due to the introduction of Cu species. Meanwhile, observing the changing trend of oxygen consumption of the two catalysts (Table S3), it can be found that the oxygen consumption of Cu/MnO2–0.25 increased, which meant that more oxygen vacancies can be formed on the surface of the catalyst. In conclusion, the strong interaction between Cu and MnO2 can activate more surface lattice oxygen to promote the catalytic performance [50]. In general, the low-temperature reduction behavior of the catalyst can reflect the lattice efficiency of the catalyst. Fig. 6b showed the H2-TPR results of the prepared sample species catalyst. It could be observed from the figure that Cu/MnO2 has two hydrogen absorption peaks. The hydrogen consumption peak at lower temperature belonged to the reduction of Cu2+→Cu0 [35], and at higher temperature the hydrogen consumption peak can be attributed to the reduction of Mn3+, Mn4+→Mn2+ [52]. The position of the reduction peak directly reflected the strength of the redox performance of the catalyst. As showed in Fig. 6b, due to the low content of Cu, the reduction peak of Cu2+→Cu0 was less obvious at low temperature. Compared with MnO2, the reduction peaks of Cu/MnO2–0.25 belonged to Mn3+, Mn4+→Mn2+, which all moved to the lower temperature, which indicated that the redox performance of Cu/MnO2–0.25 is stronger than that of MnO2, corresponding to the activity test results. It could be seen from the above results that the strong interaction (SMSI) between Cu and MnO2 supports can well promote CO reducibility. 3.5 Reaction mechanism To further understand the CO oxidation mechanism of the catalysts, in situ DRIFTS measurements were performed on MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 catalysts. Fig. 7 a and b recorded the spectra of MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 catalysts in a 50 ml/min mixture of 4000 ppm CO, 16 vol% O2 and N2 balanced. Adsorption peaks were all detected between 1200 cm−1 and 1700 cm−1, which were attributed to carbon intermediates (mainly carbonate species). Among them, the peaks near 1360 cm−1 and 1490 cm−1 belonged to monodentate carbonate species, and the peaks near 1280 cm−1, 1570 cm−1 and 1680 cm−1 belonged to bidentate carbonate species. The peaks in the range of 2000–2400 cm−1 were attributed to the vibrational absorption peaks of carbonyl species formed after CO adsorption on the catalyst surface and the rotational vibrational absorption peaks of CO2. It could be observed that the CO adsorption peaks and gas-phase CO2 peaks were weaker than those of intermediate carbonates, which may be due to the rapid oxidation of CO due to O2 supplementation. With the increase of temperature, the peak intensity of CO decreased, the peak intensity of CO2 increased and the types of carbonates gradually increased, indicating that the higher the temperature, the more intense the oxidation reaction of CO occurred. Furthermore, compared with Fig. 7a and 7b, the peak intensity of Cu/MnO2–0.25 was significantly stronger than that of MnO2. This indicated that the introduction of Cu indeed promoted the catalytic oxidation of CO. Furthermore, to determine whether the oxygen species consumed by the reaction was lattice oxygen, the spectra of Cu/MnO2–0.25 at 120 °C with and without oxygen were compared over time. As shown in Fig. 7c and 7d, the intensities of all peaks of the catalyst reached a steady state after 10 min. It has been proved by XPS and O2-TPD that the introduction of Cu enhanced the lattice oxygen activity and the ability of catalyst oxygen activation. Therefore, it is speculated that in the presence of O2, the reaction pathway was the CO molecules first chemisorb on the catalyst surface, the chemisorbed CO molecules migrated to the catalyst surface, reacted with the surface lattice oxygen to generate CO2, along with the production of intermediate products such as carbonate, and the consumed surface lattice oxygen species are supplemented by gas-phase O2. Further according to Fig. 7d, in the absence of oxygen, although the appearance of the peaks was weaker than those in the presence of O2, the adsorption peaks of CO, gas-phase CO2 and carbonate intermediates were consistent with those in the aerobic condition. Likewise, the CO adsorbed on the catalyst also gradually decreased with increasing temperature and produced CO2. In this way, we could prove that the active oxygen consumed during CO oxidation is surface lattice oxygen, which preliminarily confirmed that the reaction follows the MvK mechanism. To further confirm the reaction mechanism, we performed kinetic studies on Cu/MnO2–0.25 and measured the reaction order of CO and O2 for the catalyst. We investigated the effect of CO and O2 partial pressure on the reaction rate. As shown in Fig. 8 a the condition of constant O2 partial pressure, the CO oxidation reaction rate versus CO partial pressure (Pco) curve fits well with the data, and the CO reaction order is between 0.43–0.77, which indicates that CO molecules may first adsorb on the catalyst surface to form intermediate species instead of directly participating in the reaction. It was showed in the Fig. 8b the CO oxidation reaction rate changes very little with the gas-phase O2 partial pressure, and the O2 reaction order obtained by fitting are all around 0 [53], which indicates that the CO oxidation reaction rate is not sensitive to the gas-phase O2 partial pressure, which may be because the depleted reactive oxygen species (surface lattice oxygen) are caused by the rapid replenishment of introduced gas-phase O2. To sum up, the reaction order of CO was slightly positive, around 0.4. According to the literature, it was known that the order of CO is slightly positive. It showed that CO is weakly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and Cu single atoms are not poisoned by CO during the reaction. This corresponds to in situ infrared. It showed that the reaction order of O2 is close to 0, the zero-order reaction, and the reaction rate of the catalyst is not affected by the partial pressure of oxygen, which may be due to the surface lattice oxygen species consumed by the reaction, and O2 is easily activated and quickly replenished to oxygen vacancies superior. This corresponds to the MvK mechanism. The rate-controlling step was the reaction of adsorbed CO and lattice oxygen [40]. In order to verify how much oxygen is involved in the MvK mechanism at the catalyst surface, we did CO pulse injection control experiments of MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25. Fig. 9 showed the CO pulse adsorption peak spectra obtained for MnO2 and Cu/MnO2–0.25 after 10 pulses at 120 °C. In the experiment, we injected a fixed amount of 519 µl of CO each time and analyzed the spectra to calculate the total amount of CO involved in the reaction after ten pulses, i.e. the amount of oxygen involved in the reaction. The amount of oxygen involved in the reaction was calculated to be 11.60 µmol/g for MnO2 and 63.91 µmol/g for Cu/MnO2–0.25, which obtained the amount of oxygen involved in the MvK mechanism in the respective catalysts, and also showed that Cu/MnO2–0.25 activated more oxygen than MnO2 and therefore had better activity. Based on the above discussion, the mechanism of Cu/MnO2 catalytic oxidation of CO follows the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) model, and the MnO2 support acts as an oxygen atom donor, enabling Cu and MnO2 support to interact with strong metal support to form a single-atom catalyst. As shown in Fig. 10 , the CO molecules chemisorb on the surface Cu species. The chemisorbed CO molecules migrate to the catalyst surface and react with the surface lattice oxygen to form CO2, leaving oxygen vacancies and two electrons. This step is considered as the rate control step (RDS). The O2 molecules do not directly participate in the reaction, but is used to supplement the consumed surface lattice oxygen. At this time, two electrons are transferred to O2, and O2 may connect with the surface Cu atoms to form surface lattice oxygen, which reacts with the subsequent adsorbed CO molecules to generate CO2, and finally completes a cycle [54]. 4 Conclusions In summary, Cu/MnO2–0.25 single-atom catalyst prepared by an oxalate chelation-assisted hydrothermal method exhibited excellent performance in the medium-low temperature CO oxidation. Based on a comprehensive study of XRD, Raman spectra, TEM, XAFS, BET, etc., the differences in morphology and electronic structure of pure MnO2 support and Cu/MnO2–0.25 were explored, and it was proved that the Cu is atomically dispersed. Then, through systematic research of XPS, O2-TPD, H2-TPR, In-situ DRIFTS, etc., it was found that the strong interaction between atomically dispersed Cu and MnO2 greatly enhanced the ability of the catalyst to activate lattice oxygen and improved the catalytic performance of CO, and the kinetic studies assisted to demonstrate that CO oxidation follows the MvK (Mars-van Krevelen) reaction mechanism. Therefore, we speculated that the reaction pathway is that the CO was adsorbed on the catalysts to form Cu+-CO intermediates, which reacted with the surface lattice oxygen of the catalyst (speed-controlling step) to form intermediate products such as carbonates and finally generated CO2, the depleted surface lattice oxygen species were replenished by gas phase O2. In this paper, when the Cu content is 0.25%, the catalytic activity of the catalyst is the best, indicating that the isolated Cu single atoms activated more lattice oxygen to participate in the reaction at this time. When Cu content increases, Cu may form CuxOy clusters, and some Cu sites may be hidden by the clusters, resulting in decreased activity. In summary, compared with pure MnO2, a single-atom catalyst can be formed by adding a small amount of Cu, which greatly reduces the amount of metal while increasing the utilization of atoms and improving the catalytic activity of CO. This work not only provides an efficient system for CO oxidation, but also provides an effective method for the synthesis of transition metal SACs and deepens the understanding of the activation of reaction oxygen species via SMSI. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic oxidation of CO by single-atom transition metal catalysts has always been the focus of researchers. Herein, we report a strategy for the preparation of Cu single-atom anchored on MnO2 by oxalate chelation-assisted hydrothermal method, and the obtained Cu/MnO2–0.25 catalyst with the optimal molar ratio achieved about 90% CO conversion at 80 °C. The strong electronic interaction between Cu and MnO2 not only effectively inhibits the aggregation of Cu single atoms, but also the formed Cu-O-Mn hybrid structure activates the adjacent surface lattice oxygen, further improving the catalytic oxidation performance of CO at low and medium temperatures. The elevated activity is achieved at the single-atom active site by the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. This work provides a simple and reliable method for the rational design of stable transition metal single-atom catalysts and deepens the understanding of metal-support strong interactions (SMSI).
coredata.dc:title: Promotion effect of CO oxidation via activation of surface lattice oxygen by single atom Cu/MnO2 catalyst
